question.title: Separate the integer part from the decimal part of a real number entered from the keyboard in Java
question.body:
I have this code that separates the integer part from the decimal part

import java.io.*;
import java.util.Scanner;

public class hoja1ej9
{
    public static void main(String[] args)
    {
        Scanner dato = new Scanner(System.in);
        System.out.println("Ingrese un número real");
        double num = dato.nextDouble();

        int parteentera = (int)num;
        double partedecimal = num - parteentera;

        System.out.println(parteentera);
        System.out.println(partedecimal);
    }
}

And this is the output, but I want the decimal part to appear as if it were an integer

Ingrese un número real
45,89
45
0.8900000000000006

answers.body:
Floating point math, unfortunately, doesn't work like that.

You could input the number as a string and split it yourself:

String num = dato.next();
String[] parts = num.split("\\.");
String parteentera = parts[0];
String partedecimal = parts.length > 1 ? parts[1] : "0";

EDIT:
As @VGR pointed out in the comments, this snippet assumes that the decimal separator is the . character. A more robust solution would be to use DecimalFormatSymbols to get that character, and then use that to split the string:

String decimalSeparator = 
    Pattern.quote(String.valueOf(
        DecimalFormatSymbols.getInstance().getDecimalSeparator()));
String[] parts = num.split(decimalSeparator);

question_comments.body: It might help if you could explain why you want to do this. I suspect you are trying to do something that Java already does. Instead of an XY Problem, you might be trying to "reinvent the wheel".

This question was promoted from Staging Post, where you said you want the output to appear as "45" followed by "89", and that if the entered number was "45.089" you want the output to be "45" and "089". You should state that in the question itself, otherwise it's not clear to most people. (here's the edit link)

79609955.body: @VGR good catch! I've added it to the answer (with attribution, of course)

It appears Enrique is using a non-English locale, so it would be num.split(",") for him (or, ideally, num.split(Pattern.quote(String.valueOf(DecimalFormatSymbols.‌​getInstance().getDec‌​imalSeparator())))).
This is the correct approach, otherwise the result might have any scale like 8900000000000006
